extractions.description: This study investigates how technologically-assisted communication, as opposed to face-to-face interaction, affects inter-brain synchrony. The research focuses on mother-child interactions using hyperscanning EEG to measure neural synchrony and examines how this synchrony correlates with social behaviors such as shared gaze and empathic engagement.

type.justification: The study involved experimental methods, including hyperscanning EEG, to gather data on inter-brain synchrony during different types of social interactions.
type.quote: Applying a two-brain perspective, the current preregistered study utilized hyperscanning EEG to measure brain-to-brain synchrony in 62 mother-child pairs.

name.justification: The paper focuses on inter-brain synchrony in social contexts, which is a key topic in social neuroscience.
name.quote: Inter-brain synchrony is defined as the temporal coherence of neural dynamics between multiple brains and has become a growing focus of research in social neuroscience.

name.justification: The study utilizes hyperscanning techniques to measure inter-brain connectivity.
name.quote: The current preregistered study utilized hyperscanning EEG to measure brain-to-brain synchrony.

name.justification: EEG is used as a neuroimaging tool in the paper to study brain activity during interactions.
name.quote: EEG activity of both mother and child was recorded simultaneously and continuously throughout the experiment.

name.justification: The paper examines mother-child interactions, specifically focusing on developmental transitions during adolescence.
name.quote: We measured inter-brain synchrony between young adolescents and their mothers during live face-to-face interaction versus a remote video-chat.
